awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Revisiting Network QoS in the Cloud-based Era
awd_abstract_narration:
Today's Internet is increasingly expected to support resource-intensive interactive applications, exemplified by the emerging wave of virtual, augmented, and mixed reality applications. Unfortunately, today's public Internet offers a best-effort service, which often falls short of meeting the unprecedented resource requirements and desired goals of these applications. This project aims to achieve high Quality of Service (QoS) for these and other applications by judiciously combining existing Internet resources with additional resources drawn from the cloud, while also being cost-effective for end users. 

The principal investigators will revisit the QoS problem in the context of the emerging cloud infrastructure: the global footprint of data centers (DC) hosted by major cloud providers. These DCs have good network connectivity (both between data centers as well as to the end-users) but are costly to use. Using extensive network measurements, this project will first quantify the potential benefits of using the cloud as an overlay for wide area communication. Further, it will investigate how best-effort Internet paths can be judiciously combined with cloud overlays to provide bandwidth and latency guarantees to applications, using appropriate and economically efficient pricing mechanisms. The project, if successful, will empower the delivery of high QoS to typical, cost-sensitive end-users, potentially enabling transformative networked applications in areas like healthcare and education. Measurement and protocol insights from this project have the potential to benefit network service providers and network researchers, while students will benefit from new course material and hands-on programming projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project investigated the strategic use of cloud paths — private network pathways connecting various data centers of cloud providers — to enhance Quality of Service (QoS) for end users. Active measurements demonstrated that these cloud paths could achieve higher QoS, evidenced by lower packet loss and jitter, in comparison to standard Internet paths. The project introduced J-QoS, a novel framework consisting of multiple services, including packet forwarding, caching, and a novel packet recovery service. This recovery service utilizes coding techniques to facilitate rapid, cost-effective packet recovery, specifically tailored for interactive applications. The research encompassed the design, implementation, and evaluation of J-QoS on public cloud platforms, particularly focusing on interactive applications like augmented reality (AR) based collaboration.

Intellectual Merit: The research contributed significantly to the technical aspects of QoS.  It: i) revealed insights into the characteristics of cloud paths, ii) developed fundamental services that can be integrated to support diverse end-to-end applications, and iii) introduced a unique coding-based service for packet recovery, featuring a receiver-driven protocol and an adaptable coding mechanism suitable for various packet loss conditions.  Collaborators at Tufts investigated the human level, their user studies shed light on the effects of packet losses in AR-based collaboration, exploring potential coping strategies for users and systems.

Broader Impact: This project offered educational opportunities to two PhD candidates at Boston University, leading to numerous publications and presentations. Additionally, the research prototypes were released as open source. The PI also engaged in a range of educational efforts, integrating these research findings into courses at Boston University.
